message.body: ALL OF MY PRO CON LISTS COME OUT EVEN HELP
What's up??
Jobs. Penn vs. NIH
You for the NIH job?
*got
Congrats!
Do you still need help deciding?
I have calmed down haha...ugh I always end up leaning toward penn and then honking about it and being torn and then leaning towards penn
Yeah!
Slash it actually sounds like you've made a decision already...
What's your perspective?
I dunno I... I'm not ready to give up on either one. I need to talk to professors...I think I'm looking at it from an okay perspective but everyone I ask has a different perspective

That ultimately people from both places get into grad school so even though NIH would give me new skills that would make me marketable (work with kids, neuro, physiological stuff), I'm ultimately not as excited about those things as I am about what is studied at penn. so even though a prof might emphasize direct mentorship and gaining marketable skills, is rather do what interests me more given that I would hopefully get into grad school either way
But I've heard that interests don't matter, research quality/skills and mentorship do.
Like, in general
But I'm just more interested in the stuff at penn, despite the crazy boss thing and NIH being a more cookie cutter experience
And maybe more renowned outside the OCD/PTSD worlds?

I think you'll be able to get into grad school either way. And being more interested and committed to your job is going to enable to learn more from it and make more valuable connections. And it's not like your NOT going to be learning good things from the penn job. I don't think the penn is position is bad, or bad enough for you to take the nih position because its what you "should" do. Ultimately doing something related to your interests is going to be the biggest pro in the long run.
ï¿¼Pro/con list
But really I feel like I would defend penn harder if challenged...but I guess not if everyone else is right, you know?
That is all true

I'm not sure what you said in that last text but i feel like you want to go to penn ( and the debate comes in b/c of NIH reputation and "cookie cutter" experience). In the end, given that this is not a long-term position and that chances are great you'll get into grad school either way, the question is really what kind of an experience do you want to have? ( as opposed to what should i do; because I don't think there's a nothing you should or even have to do).
Do you want to have chance to explore a topic your interested in, that you're leaning towards working in? With some goods/bads with regards to environment but a strong support system.
Or do you want an experience in a typical but reputable environment and a new city to challenge yourself that way?
